Award.AwardTitle: The Engineering and Technicians Project ( E2T)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Mechatronics is the synergistic combination of mechanical engineering, electronic engineering and software engineering. Mechatronics serves the purposes of controlling advanced hybrid systems and has been associated with many different areas, encompassing manufacturing, motion control, robotics, intelligent control, system integration, vibration and noise control, automotive systems, automation technology, modeling and design, energy management systems and micro devices. To sum up its purpose and value, Mechatronics promotes and fosters innovation through integration. The Engineering of Engineering Technicians (E2T) at VWCC addresses the student deficiencies entering this growing interdisciplinary engineering technology field by building synergy between industry, community college faculty, and secondary career and technical education (CTE) entities to streamline a career pathway in Mechatronics. The project has three major goals: 1) to implement industry driven project based learning (PBL) modules created by secondary and post-secondary faculty in the summer institute; 2) to enhance project based activities for students by expanding summer Mechatronics and pre-engineering camps, the annual Technology Summit, and STEM Career Exploration events for underrepresented student populations; and 3) to increase the Regional Academy in Advanced Technology enrollment of underrepresented populations. An additional project objective is to enhance the ability of secondary technical education and pre engineering teachers to implement PBLs that ultimately lead to elevated proficiency in problem analysis, self-directed learning and solution based learning in the classroom with particular focus to recruit students from underrepresented populations into the Mechatronics field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Engineering of Engineering Technicians (E2T) planning project was established to strengthen the relationships with industry and secondary high school Career and Technical Education (CTE) faculty partnerships while elevating proficiency in problem analysis, self-directed learning, brainstorming and solution based learning in the classroom.

The project outcomes for E2T were significant and included the adoption of 10 Project-Based Learning (PBL) modules that have been implemented in the high school CTE programs along with curriculum to solve any PBL - Tooling U.  Tooling University is owned and operated by the Society of Manufacturing Engineers and is an online learning tool. Based on the reports from Tooling U, 250 students per year, with a total of 750 students impacted by the use of Tooling U, increasing students’ technical knowledge by 18%. In addition to receiving these resources, E2T provided the high school’s faculty with 30 Programmable Logic Controllers for use in the classroom along with training to integrate the PLCs into their curriculum.  Integrating programming in their classroom enabled recruiting students into their program.

As a result of the project, the Summer Institute was created, providing high school faculty professional development to build their capacity, stimulate student learning, and drive curriculum augmentation. Building synergy and camaraderie with the feeder high school teachers also occurred with professional development at the Hi-TEC conference, NCPN conference and NSF PI conference. To recruit students into the Mechatronics Program, the college hosted an annual STEM-H Summit that hosted over 300 students from area high schools and Career and Technology Centers.  Along with the Summer Institute, Summer Camps were offered annually to light the spark in 6-8th graders about careers in STEM.  The Mechatronics program has experienced a 10% increase in student enrollment and a 15% increase in female students.

PI Horine formed a regional collaborative partnership consisting of representatives from the manufacturing industry, education and economic development agencies. PI Horine hosted two Manufacturing Summits, bringing together industry leaders, area Career and Technical Directors, and high school CTE faculty with the purpose of identifying and developing solutions for creating workforce talent to support their needs. Attendance at each Manufacturing Summit was over 70 annually. Data collected from the two Summer Institutes was used to guide PBL development, select Industry-driven certifications and shape the approved Applied Associate of Science degree in Mechatronics Systems Engineering Technology.  PI Horine worked with Purdue University Calumet and developed an articulation agreement so students can transfer to a 4-year University.  Having the ability to transfer has also yielded greater enrollment in the degree. 

With the success of the Engineering of Engineering Technicians planning project, a new project was proposed and approved by NSF ATE.  The Partnership for Advanced Career Education in Mechatronics Engineering (PACE-ME, Federal Award ID: 1400571) project will continue the momentum of the Engineering of Engineering Technicians planning project.
